title: Expect discomfort, APRA tells super funds
text:
On Monday, Mrs Rowell sought to head off criticism that APRA might not be able to come up with a credible method for comparing funds with different investment strategies or membership characteristics.

"That’s why the final design of the heat map will be the culmination of more than a year’s considered analysis that seeks to incorporate like-for-like comparisons and appropriately reflect these differences," she said.

"Beyond any unease about benchmarks or methodology, we suspect the real concern for many trustees is the prospect of having their performance publicly exposed in a simpler, credible and insightful way by APRA – especially among those with an inkling that their place on the heat map will be at the hotter end of the colour spectrum.

"We don’t resile from the fact that the heat map is designed to challenge the trustees of underperforming products to consider where their performance needs improvement, and to take action in response.”

It is the second major speech on the topic by APRA.

APRA has been under pressure to prove it is getting tough on dud funds, following criticism by the Graeme Samuel-led capability review and the banking royal commission.

"We are in the process of finalising all the details of the methodology and measures we will use for the heat map, and exactly how we will present them," Mrs Rowell said.

"But what I can share with you is that the heat map will not include a single, overall product level assessment.

Advertisement

"Rather, the heat map will display performance across a range of metrics in the areas of investments and fees and costs, and provide indicators for trends in sustainability measures."

Retail super funds, along with some smaller industry funds, are worried that their more conservative investment strategies will make them look like they are underperforming when what they are really doing, they claim, is trying to protect the capital of typically older membership bases.

Had there not been a long bull market, they might be at the top of the performance league tables, they argue.

In September, AMP wealth boss Alex Wade said that in order to ensure members were fully informed, APRA would need to come up with a system for reporting risk-adjusted returns.

He urged the regulator to issue guidance about which types of assets should be classified as growth and which as defensive.

“At present, many members rely on fund labels such as ‘balanced’ to inform their judgment, without realising that the underlying risk in these funds can be quite different,” Mr Wade said.

“Some funds classify illiquid investments, such as unlisted property and infrastructure, as defensive.

“In many cases, these investments have performed well, however, due to the fact they can’t be offloaded as quickly as shares or other liquid investments in the event of a downturn, they potentially carry more risk."
description: Crummy superannuation funds are right to be uncomfortable about the impending release of performance appraisals that will expose high fees and poor returns, APRA says.
